CHIT-CHAT LOCALS.
Gathered by our Reporters.

T T T. Try for Mr. T. Walters & Co.
Pocket and Office Diaries for 1869 at Cassin's Bookstore.
J. M. R. Neely, school teacher at the School House, Steves for his field of labor today.
The Privy Council have granted permission to the R. V. Y. K. to cross the C. F. R.
The police boys are getting up a grand exhibition of skating on the lake in the course of a week's work.
The public school opened after the Christmas holidays, on Monday last.
There are now 160 names on the roll.
Mrs. McKay, wife of the Rev. John McKay, of Almonte mission, has returned from her visit with Mr. Head.
The town council met in the council chamber for the transaction of business.
The Rev. Canon Fleet, public school inspector, got back from Snake Plain this evening, where he had been visiting the natives.
Mr. J. F. A. Still, school teacher, arrived back from Duck Lake last Saturday.
He had been away during the Christmas holidays with his daughter.
The annual meeting of the Sask. Rifle Association was held in the Council chamber on Wednesday next, 16th inst., for the purpose of electing officers and transacting other general business.
A full attendance was present.
The bell for the Nasket Academy arrived yesterday and placed in position in the school house tomorrow evening by Mr. A. Goodfellow.
It is to be hoped that the correct time will be kept at the Academy and that the bell will be rung regularly.
Travelers coming from Green Lake say that the snow was very light and nothing to be complained of.
The New Year's day was so warm up at Mistassini that the roads were all clear and both sides of woods were seen in several places.
The balance of the snow was gone.
We are offered a store Flannel at 25c per yard, Lamb Caps for 8s, Lambs Cap 8s, Tweed Overcoats 8s, Lambs Cap 8s, 7s, 6s, 5s, 4s.
All others appear to be cut in same proportion.
Water and milk are still scarce.
Tickets are out now for the complimentary dinner to be given to Lord Ed. Irvin at the Queen Hotel on Tuesday evening.
We are also offered a large number of tickets next, and all those who wish to do honor to the gallant colonel will find better value than at once from this source.
The thermometer indicated colder weather last night than they had ever known, but there was no indication that it would be zero.
For the last month or so we have had beautiful weather, the thermometer has been above zero during the day and below zero during the night, and during the days there would only be a few degrees difference.
Fever on the increase and is now in half-a-dozen homes.
A meeting of the town council was called to consider the advisability of having the streets made under quarantine.
The foregoing paragraph appeared in the telegraph of December 25th, the Herald, and a malicious falsehood has been sent about the whole.
Fever was certainly in town but there are three families that it, and the doctor have visited, and yet the medals are alone able to be around.
Will G. Clark, baggage-master, W. & A. Railway, Amosaple, N.S., writes—Please send me another bottle of Nauvoo Pills, my first bottle of Nauvoo Pills I have used it according to instructions it would have cured me if it had not been for that another person.
Are you concerned with the welfare of your family?

THIS PAPER MAY BE FOUND IN THE FOLLOWING PLACES:
Rogers' Bookstore, Prince Albert; Royal Hotel, Prince Albert; Bromley & Co., Prince Albert; Robertson & Robertson, Prince Albert; and the offices of the Prince Albert Times.

FRIDAY, JAN. 11, 1889.
We hope that our citizens will take advantage of Tuesday night's banquet to express the esteem in which we feel sure Col. Irvine is held by them.

The list of buildings purchased in another column erected in this town in the year just closed is a most creditable one; but there is yet no building of any kind erected so far, at a cost of nearly $3,000; there has been a considerable amount of money spent in finishing buildings put up under former years and we have doubtless omitted one or two of late years erected. When we consider that there is no migration to the place the increase in building is something remarkable, and the substantial and costly nature of most of the buildings erected speaks very highly of the taste of the citizens and the increasing number of citizens in that time.

Now that the municipal elections are over and the excitement occasioned thereby has subsided, we extend our congratulations to the successful candidates, and express the hope that they will drop all private and petty jealousies and direct their energies to the welfare and prosperity of the best interest of the town. We do not agree with those who say that we have the poorest council that it was possible to get on the other hand we believe that it would be difficult to find a more honourable or more practical or watch closer over interests. In Mr. Knowles we have a mayor who is in every way fitted for that position; we feel confident that our interests are safe in his keeping and that he will see that the public money will be wisely expended in the different wards of the town than have hitherto been. We have full confidence that the policy of the new council will be one of economy and that at the end of the year they will go out of office with a clean record.

Some time ago we took the liberty of bringing to the notice of the Dominion Government at the first it is the expense of the late Assembly elections in the districts of Prince Albert and Kinistino had not been paid. We regret that, so far as known by the returning officers for those districts, they have not yet been paid, and those who acted as district returning officers and in other capacities are still anxiously waiting for their money. In some cases those officers have had to travel over 600 miles at a very large personal outlay and it is a gross injustice to keep them waiting so long as they have. The same now holds good and suffered over six months and should move in order for the Government to send up some officials from Ottawa to investigate the case. If there was anything irregular in the matter it should have been brought into the hands of the authorities sooner and settled one way or another; anything would have been more satisfactory than the treatment than that has been meted out to the returning officers and their deputies in the districts mentioned.

We have for some time felt that steps should be taken towards the formation of a society here having for its object the collection and preservation of information relative to the past and present history of the country; in other words a Scientific and Historical Society, and it ought to include a literary institute as well. We have considered several men who ought to be most likely to take an interest in such a society and all whom we have seen favor the project. We do not anticipate that its expense would be very great, with the result for the benefit of the town it would be invaluable. The country has a past history that should be preserved, and now is the time that it should be done. Many interesting facts, which at present are unknown except to a few natives, are buried in the memory of the Indians. Such a society would hang as its objects the collection of natural history specimens and other scientific works. The formation of a literary society would be of the utmost value and the residents of the town more in need of it today. We see no reason why the scheme could not be successfully carried out, and trust that some one will take the initiative and bring a number of our interested. No harm will be done by discussing the matter and until good may result.

TIMES OFFICE
Prince Albert
THE ELECTIONS.

Monday last being the first of the new year it was the sign laid down in the Constitution ordinance for holding the election. Only two—Knowles and Knowles of the same name—were nominated for mayor, and the poll was closed Knowles had a majority of twenty-three votes. Of the 123 electors who voted only 120 cast their ballot for mayor, which shows that there were several who did not take part in the majority contest. For councillor in Ward No. 1 the electors were equally divided in their choice between Knowles and Donaldson, the former being declared Knowles elected. In Ward No. 2 a split of about equal strength was shown between Donaldson and Knowles, the latter being elected. In Ward No. 3 Knowles was returned by a majority of twenty-eight votes, while Donaldson received thirty-two votes. In Ward No. 4 Knowles received twenty-eight votes, while Donaldson received thirty-two votes.

WARD NO. 1

Knowles 12
Donaldson 12

Total number of votes cast 24

WARD NO. 2

Knowles 27
Donaldson 27

Total number of votes cast 54

WARD NO. 3

Knowles 38
Donaldson 38

Total number of votes cast 76

WARD NO. 4

Knowles 56
Donaldson 56

Total number of votes cast 112

NOTICE.

Application will be made to the Provincial Court for an order declaring Knowles elected mayor. The electors of Ward No. 1 have been asked to meet at the residence of Mr. Knowles at 7 o'clock this evening to consider the matter.

J. FRASER TIMS,
Fort Saskatchewan Alta.

Mahaffey & Clinkskill,
Battleford, Sask.
Building Operations

IN 1888.

The following list, as nearly as we can ascertain, is a correct statement of the buildings erected in this town last year. In each case we give the name of the contractor and the cost of the building. It will be seen that there were twenty-five new buildings erected, at an aggregate cost of $45,910.

The first in importance in the Niedert, Kondorberg, is the log hill near the court house. It is a two-story brick building, 37x20 feet, with a bell-tower at the front of the roof and a porch over the front door, and is quite an ornament to the town. Through the courtesy of the contractors who built it, we have been able to see inside, and we must say that no better workmanship has ever been displayed in the North. The log hill contains five class rooms (20x35) fitted up for public instructions, but also used as present at a music room; hall, 30x60 feet; chapel, 20x30 feet; library, 12x12 feet; and 12x12 feet. On the second floor there are two class rooms 21x25 feet, reception rooms 12x12 feet, and a large room 12x12 feet, half 10x12 feet, the same being a fine piece of workmanship. The building is well lighted, and everything about it appears to be perfect. There are five class rooms now furnished with desks, to the number of thirty, the gift of Mr. J. M. McLeod. Mr. J. M. McLeod did a fine chair-case piece of work on the brick, stone and plaster work for $2,500, and A. & W. H. Goodfellow did all the carpenter work for $1,500. Mr. J. M. McLeod did all the carpenter work, etc., for $5,000. Total cost, with extras, about $8,500.

The log hill was built, and also factory work to the value of $2,000.

Besides the above, a large amount of money was spent on the school and Court house, which would bring the total improvements up to about $800,000 for the year.

Money raised by Board manufacturers disposed of $300,000 brick.

During last year there was over $1,000 expended by the town on streets and other improvements.

CURLIANA.

On Saturday last our wrestling games were played between two rinks chosen from the prominent and vice-president. The day was very fine for curling and some good play was made. At the close of the day the vice-president was 12 points ahead. The following is the score and rinks:

Having enlarged our premises to double their original size, we would respectfully call the attention of the travelling public to their convenience.

Well and river water almost at the door.

We have also added some horses to our stable, and a list of prices remains, and the public can depend upon getting a turn-out as can be had west of Winnipeg, at reasonable rates.

Boarders taken at reasonable prices.
